post.title: 01-foreward
post.message: The Dawn of a New Era Till July 23, 1970, Oman remained oblivious to the march of human civilisation. An isolated state, it had no relations with other Arab or Islamic countries and the same isolation pervaded all aspects of Omanis’ lives. Radios were banned, healthcare was virtually non-existent. In 1970, there was only one missionary hospital in Muttrah and a handful of admission units in Muscat. Education too cut a sorry figure with three schools existing across the whole State. On an average one school was built every 19 years. Women endured agonies for their children who toiled in the fields, working with primitive tools and struggling with paltry water rations. The new dawn appeared on 23 July, 1970, by way of His Majesty Sultan Qaboos Bin Said’s accession to the throne. Withoutdelay, he invited those who had left Oman to return to their homeland, calling on them to join him in working together to improve the conditions of the country. What followed was nothing less than a miracle – the Sultanate embarked on a phase of frenzied development. By 1975,there were 262 schools and institutions, comprising 213 primary schools, 45 preparatory schools, three secondary schools and one teacher training institute. An administrative structure was established, new laws promulgated, infrastructure development took place and the Sultanate of Oman made its presence felt amongst the comity of nations. On the 40th anniversary of the Blessed Renaissance, Progress takes a look at various landmarks in the Sultanate’s onward march towards development, modernisation and prosperity. We also convey our heartfelt gratitude to His Majesty for his visionary guidance and nation building efforts.

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: THE SULTANATE’S 40STELLAR ACHIEVEMENTS

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: In forty years since the Blessed Renaissance the Sultanate has achieved what would have taken others many more decades. As a tribute to His Majesty Sultan Qaboos Bin Said’s visionary leadership, we take a walk down memory lane identifying 40 landmark events that have been fundamental in Oman’s transition from an underdeveloped and isolated country to a modern, dynamic and progressive nation.

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: 1970 By August the erstwhile name of the country, Sultanate of Muscat and Oman was abolished and the geographical entity known as the Sultanate of Oman was born. His Majesty Sultan Qaboos bin Said also replaced the plain red national flag with the distinctive red, white and green standard. 1971 The name of Oman’s currency was changed from Saidi Rial to Omani Rial. The Omani Rial became the official currency of the country. 1972 Diplomatic relations were established between Oman and Britain, India, Pakistan, USA, Iran, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, France, Jordan, the UAE, Kuwait and Bahrain. Oman gave applications to join the League of Arab Nations and the United Nations, both of which were successful. The move changed Oman’s isolationist approach on the international stage.

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: 1973 Oman becomes a member of the Non-Aligned group of Nations. The membership enhanced Oman’s status internationally and underlined its non aligned approach. The Seeb inernational airport was opened replacing the airstrip at Bait al Falaj. This was an immediate testimony to the country’s progress and modernisation. The airport also became a crucial link to the outside world. 1974 His Majesty visits the United States of America reinforcing the Sultanate’s outward looking and internationalist outlook.The effort was to have a pragmatic approach to bilateral relations emphasising underlying geostrategic realities rather than temporary ideological positions. On 1 January, the Government of Oman accquired a 25 percent shareholding in Petroleum Development Oman (PDO); six months later the shareholding was increased to 60 per cent. As a result, the foreign interest in PDO was now made up of the Shell (34 per cent), Compagnie Française des Petroles (4 per cent) and Partex (2 per cent). These holdings have remained unchanged to this day.

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: 1974 A modern port Mina Qaboos port replaced the tiny ancient port of Muscat. The new port had a capacity to handle two million tonnes of cargo annually. The port has improved and expanded over the years. 1975 The Central Bank of Oman starts operations. This was a natural outcome of the steady evolution of the monetary system in the Sultanate coupled with the prospects of the vast economic developments the country was about to witness. 1976 The first Five-Year plan was introduced. The plan focused on developing new sources of national revenue, equitable distribution of wealth, creating basic infrastructure etc. The country has implemented seven five year plans since then. 1978 The inauguration of gas plant at Yibal on 29 October, marked the beginning of the Sultanate’s gas industry. Thirty years after the start of gas production, close to half of PDO’s production is in the form of gas and condensate.

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: 1979 Alarmed by the depletion of the Arabian Oryx by poachers, His Majesty established the Arabian Oryx Project at Jiddat al-Hirasis, which successfully reintroduced indigenous species to the wild. 1981 A state consultative assembly was formed as an initiative of the Agriculture and Fisheries Board. The private sector members were represented by the Omani Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the remainder were appointed by the government. Thus eleven years after coming to power His Majesty reiterated the philosophy underpinning the type of democracy that he sought for the country. 1982 Oman came to its own as an oil refining nation with the inauguration of the Mina Al Fahal, the first refinery in the Sultanate. The Rima oil fields also came on stream during the same year 1985 A Royal Oman Symphony Orchestra (ROSO) was formed under the aegis of the Royal Guard of Oman. The project was unique as only Omani nationals were employed as players. ROSO gave its inaugural concert on 1 July 1987 only one year after the beginning of music training.

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: 1986 Sultan Qaboos University was inaugurated and received its first batch of students. The University has grown into an august educational institute in the region over the years. 1987 The Royal Hospital Ghubra was inaugrated. The hospital is now considered as one of the most modern and specialist referral institutions in the Middle East. 1989 In May, the Muscat Securities Market (MSM) was founded by a Royal Decree. The MSM was established to increase investment opportunities in Omani stocks by freeing up the share market and allowing for private and corporate investment in joint and mixed stock companies. The exchange has acquired the reputation of being one of the most stable markets in the region 1991 During the 20th National Day celebrations, His Majesty announced the establishment of a Majlis A’Shura, a State Consultative Council whose members were to represent the 59 wilayats of Oman.

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: 1993 Oman Air, the flagship company of the Sultanate of Oman’s Civil Aviation sector, commenced operations. Starting off as a regional player, Oman Air has witnessed rapid growth since the time it was established. It has played a major role in making Muscat a major traffic hub in the Middle East providing a fillip to commercial, industrial and tourism activities 1994 Established by a Royal Decree Oman LNG LLC produces and sells Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) and its by-product Natural Gas Liquids (NGLs). The company undertakes activities necessary to liquefy, store, transport and market Oman’s natural gas and to deliver LNG to international customers 1996 His Majesty issued a royal decree promulgating a basic law considered by the government to be a constitution which, among other things, clarifies the royal succession, provides for a prime minister, bars ministers from holding interests in companies doing business with the government, establishes a bicameral legislature, and guarantees basic civil liberties for Omani citizens. Vision Oman 2020 gets launched. It represents a dividing line between two stages of the Sultanate’s economic and social development, marking both the end of initial development upto the country’s Silver Jubilee celebrations in 1995, and a new journey into the third millennium

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: 2000 In October, Oman became a member of the World Trade Organisation. The Sultanate is also a founding member of the Indian Ocean Rim Association. These measures have enhanced its stature in the international arena. World Trade Organisation 2001 The Sanad project was launched in October, with a RO2 million donation from the government. The project trains young Omanis to set up their own small businesses like supermarkets. On 4 May, the Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque in Bausher, Muscat was inaugurated by His Majesty, who led the prayers for the opening of this spectacular, holy edifice. Construction of the mosque started six years ago and the completed building is arguably the largest and most beautiful building in the Sultanate.

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: 2002 A concession agreement was signed between the Government of Oman and the Port of Rotterdam to develop and manage the Sohar Industrial Port Company. This includes developing a zone for heavy industries and building cargo terminals in an area of approximately 2,000 hectares for the next 25 years. The Sohar Industrial Port Company has 50:50 participation between the Omani government and the Port of Rotterdam. In November, the right to vote was granted to every Omani citizen, both male and female, over the age of twenty-one years 2004 Oman’s largest tourism development ‘The Wave’ was launched. Stretching along 7.3 kms of pristine beachfront just west of Muscat and occupying 195 hectares, the $805 million (RO 310mn) project is one of the leading Integrated Tourism Complexes, allowing foreigners to buy property. 2005 The government started implementing the liberalisation of the telecom sector in line with the World Trade Organisation (WTO) agreement. Beginning March 2005, the industry witnessed competition in the mobile sector through the licensing of a second mobile operator - Nawras 2006 Information Technology Authority (ITA) was set up by the Royal Decree 52/2006 promulgated on the 31 May. ITA is responsible for implementing national IT infrastructure projects and supervising all projects related to implementation of the Digital Oman Strategy. It also provides professional leadership to various other e-Governance initiatives of the Sultanate e.oman

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: 2006 In July, the International Heritage Committee selected five Omani aflaj to be included under UNESCO’s World Heritage List. The aflaj are: Dareez at Nizwa, Khatmin at Birkat al Mauz, Malki at Izki, Maisir at Rustaq and Jaylah in the Eastern Hajar. 2008 One of Oman’s finest sporting episodes occurred in April, when Muscat received the Olympic Torch. The city was one of the 22 capitals around the world to be chosen for this event and the only Middle Eastern capital to enjoy the honour. The national ePayment Gateway (ePG) is formally launched on the 30 August. The launch of the ePG ushered the transformation of Oman’s eGovernment implementation forward to the transactional phase. The ePG provides an operational component of the e-governance infrastructure and full e-commerce facilities that allow secure online payments (e-payments).

post.title: 02-milestone
post.message: 2009 The United States-Oman Free Trade Agreement (FTA) came into force on 1 January. As a result 100 per cent bilateral trade in industrial and consumer products became duty-free immediately. Oman and the US will provide each other immediate duty-free access on virtually all products in their tariff schedules and will phase out tariffs on the remaining handful of products within ten years The Omani Women’s Symposium, held in Sohar in October recommended a number of measures to empower women. One of the interesting outcomes of the symposium was to mark Omani Women’s Day on 17 October every year. Brand Oman’s logo is launched. The logo takes inspiration from the wonderful diversity of Oman incorporating various elements like, Arabic calligraphy, marine environment, magnificent landscape, local textiles, Oman’s historic leadership in trade and pioneering role in exploration and frankincense. Oman won the Gulf Cup for football for the first time, defeating regional heavyweights Saudi Arabia on penalties in the final. The two sides had been locked at 0-0 after extra-time, but the hosts, led by veteran French coach Claude Le Roy, held their nerve in the shoot-out winning 6-5 2010 The Sultanate started taxing all firms whether they were local or foreign equally. Prior to this Omani businesses paid a maximum of 12 per cent while foreign-owned ones were taxed at up to 30 per cent. This gave locals an automatic advantage, deterring foreign companies from coming to the country. The equitable structure is expected to encourage more foreign investment.

post.title: 03-Economy
post.message: ECONOMIC OVERVIEW

post.title: 03-Economy
post.message: THE OMANI ECONOMY:DEVELOPMENTS AND ACHIEVEMENTS Oman has seen significant economic development by adopting prudent economic management, strengthening its financial system and advancing the economic diversification programme

post.title: 03-Economy

post.title: 03-Economy
post.message: POSITIVE OUTLOOK The overall economic outlook for Oman remains positive for 2010 despite heightened global uncertainties

post.title: 03-Economy
post.message: Capital store

post.title: 03-Economy
post.message: Oman’s macro-economic performance in 2009 was adversely affected mainly due to global recession and sharp decline in crude oil prices in the international markets. Gross Domestic Product (GDP) at current market prices contracted by 23.5 per cent in 2009 as against robust growth for five consecutive years since 2004. Despite 7.1 per cent rise in crude oil production, contraction of nominal GDP directly originating from the hydrocarbon sector was higher at 38 percent in 2009 compared to 7.4 percent decline in nonpetroleum GDP. As a result, the share of hydrocarbon sector in the overall nominal GDP declined from 50.5 per cent in 2008 to 40.9 per cent in 2009, while the share of non-petroleum GDP increased from 50.6 per cent to 61.3 per cent during the same period.

post.title: 03-Economy
post.message: Al Turki Building & Civil Construction Marble & Stone Building Material Steel Fabrication Landscaping & Irrigation Oil & Gas Services GRC/GRP/GRG Joinery & Carpentry Aluminium Fabrication AL TURKI ENTERPRISES L.L.C

post.title: 03-Economy
post.message: Inflationary pressures in Oman abated significantly in 2009 mainly due to global recession and consequent fall in commodity prices, including that of oil and natural gas in the international markets. Average Consumer Price Index (CPI) for the Sultanate decelerated to 3.4 per cent in 2009 as against a recent peak of 12.4 per cent in 2008.

post.title: 03-Economy
post.message: Sohar Aluminium

post.title: 03-Economy
post.message: Despite slump in global demand, total non-oil exports of Omani origin registered only a modest decline of 5.8 percent to RO 1,849.5 million in 2009 from RO 1,962.9 million in 2008. While export receipts from “mineral products” and “ live animals and animal products” declined by 35.7 percent and 27.8 percent in 2009, “base metals and articles thereof,” “plastic, rubber & articles thereof” and “products of chemicals and allied industries” recorded growth of 122.8 percent, 33.7 percent and 23.6 percent, respectively. The increase in receipts from non-oil exports of certain commodities during 2009 was mainly attributed to start-up of operations (at full capacity) at several industrial projects, including Sohar Aluminum, Sohar International Urea and Chemical Industries, etc.

Oman is perhaps the only country in the world, simultaneously adopting steam injection, polymer flooding and miscible gas injection to boost production By HE Dr Mohammed bin Hamad Al Rumhi, Minister for Oil and Gas

post.title: 11-infrastrurcture
post.message: An obscure fishing village is making way for a splendid industrial port city, complete with international airport, free zone, tourism district, rail network and all the modern amenities of a world-class socio-industrial development Given Duqm’s proximity to the prolific oilfields of the Wusta region, the government is keen to establish a world-scale integrated oil refinery and petrochemicals complex within the industrial area

post.title: 11-infrastrurcture
post.message: Oman’s biggest free zone scheme by far is under development adjacent to the hugely successful Sohar Industrial Port in the Batinah region. Freezone Sohar is being developed by Sohar International Development Company (SIDC)

post.title: 11-infrastrurcture
post.message: Majan Consolidated Co LLC

post.title: 11-infrastrurcture
post.message: ON COURSE Equally ambitious will be a Free Trade Zone and Industrial Area envisioned at Duqm in the Wusta region. Singapore-based international consultant Jurong has been selected by the government to undertake the master-plan study of the scheme. The Duqm Free Trade Zone and Industrial Area is proposed to be housed on a 24,000-hectare plot not far from the site of the Duqm port and dry dock complex currently under construction.

post.title: 11-infrastrurcture
post.message: Gulf Agency Company Oman LLC

post.title: 11-infrastrurcture
post.message: On a more modest scale is the Al Mazyounah Free Zone straddling the Oman- Yemen border at Mazyounah. Administered by the Public Establishment for Industrial Estates (PEIE), the newly established facility is expected to attract investments in smallscale ventures

post.message: The size of the country’s national shipping fleet has gone from naught to 50 vessels within this relatively brief period, underscoring the government’s ambition to create a shipping industry that exploits opportunities created by investments in the industrial, petrochemicals and maritime sectors

post.title: 14-Information comm
post.message: The total IT spending in Oman in 2009 was $309 million. Half of it was spent on hardware. With economy looking to improve and crude oil prices being stable at around $70-80 per barrel, the future of IT looks bright in the coming years

post.title: 14-Information comm
post.message: Oman lays great emphasis on its tourism sector as a powerful catalyst for foreign investment and general socio-economic development

post.title: 14-Information comm
post.message: Despite suffering a setback last year, with the sector shrinking 8.3 per cent according to the World Travel and Tourism Council (WTTC), Oman is nonetheless tipped by the organisation to be the Middle East’s number-one growth market this year, and number three globally Investment drive

post.message: FLIGHT-PLAN TO PROSPERITY Multi-billion dollar investments in new airports, expanded gateways and a modern national airline fleet, promise to unleash a tailwind in economic benefits for the Sultanate, primarily in the form of enhanced tourism traffic and investment inflows

post.title: 14-Information comm
post.message: Aviation

post.title: 14-Information comm
post.message: The country’s aviation sector is undergoing a dramatic transformation. New airports are taking shape at Ras al Hadd, Duqm, Adam and Sohar, while international gateways in Muscat and Salalah are being overhauled to world-class standards

post.title: 14-Information comm
post.message: Times of Oman

post.title: 14-Information comm
post.message: Adam Airport will be operational by the end of this year. The facility, featuring a modest-size passenger terminal and VIP Lounge, will be officially inaugurated in 2012

FEEDING THE NATION The agriculture sector is undergoing a shift with stress towards modernisation of infrastructure and introduction of new technologies The region’s oldest irrigation system is still the main source of irrigation in Oman and a big water resource. The pattern is still prevalent in many towns and villages in Oman 15-tourism .


Agriculture in the Sultanate is mostly small scale and part of the traditional life with 84% of agricultural holdings less than two Feddan in area. However, majority of the Omani population benefits in one way or another from the agricultural sector output. 15-tourism .
